page.title: 13ENVIRONS OF NEWHAVEN
page.content: Newhaven is situated in the Ouse Valley, the river estuary providing a busy port and harbour. The surrounding downs and 3 farms are largely pasture and arable land. On the coast, chalk cliffs stretch to the west, ending at the breakwater. At the harbour entrance the East and West piers channel the shipping. The pebble beach of Seaford Bay reveals some sand at low tide. The town has architectural variety. St. Michael's Church dates from 1120. Built of flint stone and Caen rock, the style, particularly the axial tower and apsidal east end, is one rarely found in Britain. Enlarged in the nineteenth century, the church still holds regular Sunday services attracting a congregation of between 80-100 people.
